intro: Haplopappus phyllocephalus subsp. typicus, commonly known as the leafy pappus, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and distinctive leaf morphology. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, exhibiting adaptations such as succulent leaves to conserve water. Its leaves are lanceolate and often have a bluish-green hue, while the flowers are small and inconspicuous, arranged in a dense cluster. The species is notable for its unique sub-specific traits that distinguish it from other members of the Haplopappus genus.
